sen.j: 江戸氏（えどし）は日本の氏族の一つ。
sen.e: The Edo clan was a shizoku (family) in Japan.
The Edo clan was a shizoku (family) in Japan.
The Edo clan was a shizoku (family) in Japan.

sen.j: 歴史上、武蔵国と常陸国で勢力を振るった氏族が有名である。
sen.e: In Japanese history, the Edo clan who were in power in the Musashi and Hitachi Provinces are the most well-known.
In Japanese history, the Edo clan who were in power in Musashi and Hitachi Provinces are particularly well-known.
In Japanese history, the Edo clan who were in power in Musashi and Hitachi Provinces are particularly well-known.

sen.j: 武蔵江戸氏は、桓武平氏秩父氏の一族。
sen.e: The Musashi-Edo clan was a lineage of the Kanmu-Heishi Chichibu clan.
The Musashi-Edo clan was a family of the Chichibu clan of Kanmu Heishi (Taira clan originated from the Emperor Kanmu).
sen.cmt: 例えば「清和源氏」は「清和天皇を祖とする源氏」という定訳があり、桓武平氏も同様の補足を付けました。
sen.e: The Musashi-Edo clan was a family of the Chichibu clan of Kanmu Heishi (Taira clan originated from the Emperor Kanmu).

sen.j: 武蔵国江戸郷 (武蔵国)に本拠地を置き、のちに現在の皇居を本拠に勢力を張った一族。
sen.e: Their home ground was in Edo-go, Musashi Province and later on the clan was based where the current Imperial Palace is.
The clan was based in Edo-go, Musashi Province in the beginning and later shifted their base to the place where the Imperial Palace stands today.
The clan was based in Edo-go, Musashi Province in the beginning and later shifted their base to the place where the Imperial Palace stands today.

sen.j: 常陸江戸氏は、藤原秀郷那珂氏の一族。
sen.e: The Hitachi-Edo clan was a lineage of FUJIWARA no Hidesato and the Naka clan.
The Hitachi-Edo clan was a family of the Naka clan related to FUJIWARA no Hidesato.
sen.cmt: 「藤原秀郷の流れを汲む那珂氏の一族」と解しました。
sen.e: The Hitachi-Edo clan was a family of the Naka clan related to FUJIWARA no Hidesato.

sen.j: 常陸国那珂郡江戸郷 (常陸国)に本拠地を置いたが、後に水戸城に移る。
sen.e: Their home ground was in Edo-go, Naka District, Hitachi Province but later on the clan was based in the Mito-jo Castle.
The clan was based in Edo-go, Naka County, Hitachi Province in the beginning and later shifted their base to Mito-jo Castle.
The clan was based in Edo-go, Naka County, Hitachi Province in the beginning and later shifted their base to Mito-jo Castle.

sen.j: 武蔵江戸氏
sen.e: The Musashi-Edo Clan
The Musashi-Edo Clan
The Musashi-Edo Clan

sen.j: 平安時代の末（11世紀）に秩父重綱の四男江戸重継が武蔵国江戸郷を相続し、「江戸四郎」を称したのが始まりとされる。
sen.e: The clan started when, in the 11th century, Shigetsugu EDO, the fourth son of Shigetsuna CHICHIBU, inherited Edo-go, Musashi Province and called himself 'Shiro EDO'.
The clan started when, in the 11th century, Shigetsugu EDO, the fourth son of Shigetsuna CHICHIBU, inherited Edo-go, Musashi Province and called himself 'Shiro EDO.'
sen.cmt: 句点の打ち方を修正しました。
sen.e: The clan started when, in the 11th century, Shigetsugu EDO, the fourth son of Shigetsuna CHICHIBU, inherited Edo-go, Musashi Province and called himself 'Shiro EDO.'

sen.j: 重継は現在の皇居の本丸、二の丸周辺の台地城に居館を構えたという。
sen.e: Shigetsugu was believed to have lived in the highland castle near the Honmaru (the keep) and the Ninomaru (second bailey) of the current Imperial Palace.
Shigetsugu is believed to have lived in a highland castle near the Honmaru (the keep) and the Ninomaru (second bailey) of the current Imperial Palace.
Shigetsugu is believed to have lived in a highland castle near the Honmaru (the keep) and the Ninomaru (second bailey) of the current Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 江戸氏は1180年に源頼朝が挙兵した時、すでに武蔵国内の最有力の武家の一角となっていた。
sen.e: The Edo clan was already one of the most powerful samurai clans of the Musashi Province when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised his army in 1180.
The Edo clan was already one of the most powerful samurai clans of Musashi Province when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised his army in 1180.
sen.cmt: Musashi Province の前の定冠詞を削除しました。
sen.e: The Edo clan was already one of the most powerful samurai clans of Musashi Province when MINAMOTO no Yoritomo raised his army in 1180.

sen.j: 重継の子江戸重長は初め頼朝と対立して頼朝方の三浦氏を伐ったが、後に和解して鎌倉幕府の御家人となった。
sen.e: In the beginning, Shigetsugu's son Shigenaga EDO was opposed to Yoritomo and killed a Miura clan who was on Yoritomo's side but later on they made peace and he became a shogunal retainer of the Kamakura Shogunate.

In the beginning, Shigetsugu's son Shigenaga EDO, opposed to Yoritomo, killed a Miura clan member on the Yoritomo side, but after they made peace, he became a shogunal retainer of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

In the beginning, Shigetsugu's son Shigenaga EDO, opposed to Yoritomo, killed a Miura clan member on the Yoritomo side, but after they made peace, he became a shogunal retainer of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 弘長元年10月3日_(旧暦)（1261年）、江戸氏の一族の一人であった地頭江戸長重が正嘉の飢饉による荒廃で経営が出来なくなった江戸郷前島村（現在の東京駅周辺）を北条氏得宗家に寄進してその被官となり、1315年までに得宗家から円覚寺に再寄進されている事が記録として残されている。
sen.e: According to records, in November 4, 1261, one of the Edo clan and Jito (manager and lord of an estate) Nagashige EDO donated Maejima-mura village of Edo-go to the Hojo-Tokuso family when he could no longer manage the village after the havoc from a famine, he became their Hikan (lower-level bureaucrat); and by 1315, the village was donated again from the Tokuso family to the Enkaku-ji Temple.

According to records, in November 4, 1261, one of the Edo clan and Jito (manager and lord of an estate) Nagashige EDO donated Maejima-mura village of Edo-go (present-day Tokyo Station and its neighborhood) to the Tokuso family (the direct line of the regency Hojo family) when he could no longer manage the village because of the Shoka Famine, which incident led him to serve the family, and by 1315, the village was donated again from the Tokuso family to the Enkaku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: ・抜けが幾つかあったので補いました。・「被官」は中世の場合主人に仕える下級武士のことを意味するので、これを採用しました。
sen.e: According to records, in November 4, 1261, one of the Edo clan and Jito (manager and lord of an estate) Nagashige EDO donated Maejima-mura village of Edo-go (present-day Tokyo Station and its neighborhood) to the Tokuso family (the direct line of the regency Hojo family) when he could no longer manage the village because of the Shoka Famine, which incident led him to serve the family, and by 1315, the village was donated again from the Tokuso family to the Enkaku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府が滅びると、江戸氏は南北朝時代 (日本)の騒乱において初め新田義貞に従って南朝 (日本)方につき、後に北朝 (日本)に帰順して鎌倉公方に仕えた。
sen.e: When the Kamakura Shogunate was overthrown, the Edo clan were following Yoshizada NITTA at first in the strife-torn state of the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to be sided with the Southern Court but later on changed to the Northern Court to support Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of Kamakura Region).

During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts following the fall of the Kamakura bakufu, the Edo clan took Yoshisada NITTA's side to support the Southern Court, but later switched to the Northern Court's side to serve Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of Kamakura Region).

During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts following the fall of the Kamakura bakufu, the Edo clan took Yoshisada NITTA's side to support the Southern Court, but later switched to the Northern Court's side to serve Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of Kamakura Region).

sen.j: 江戸長門・江戸高良らは畠山国清の命により矢口渡で新田義興謀殺に加わった。
sen.e: Nagato EDO and Takayoshi EDO involved in the killing of Yoshioki NITTA at Yaguchi no Watashi (The Yaguchi Bridge) on Kunikiyo HATAKEYAMA's order.
sen.cmt: 「江戸高良」は読みが不明です。
sen.e: Nagato EDO and 江戸高良 became involved in the killing of Yoshioki NITTA at Yaguchi no Watashi (The Yaguchi Bridge) on Kunikiyo HATAKEYAMA's order.
sen.cmt: 江戸高良は読み方が不明のため、日本語表記に戻しました。江戸長門も読み方は確認できませんでしたが、翻訳を採用しました。
sen.e: Nagato EDO and 江戸高良 became involved in the killing of Yoshioki NITTA at Yaguchi no Watashi (The Yaguchi Bridge) on Kunikiyo HATAKEYAMA's order.

sen.j: その後、武蔵平一揆で敗退するなどして衰退した。
sen.e: After that, the clan lost power when losing at the Musashi hei ikki Riot, etc.
After that, the clan, who suffered a defeat in Musashi hei ikki Riot, lost power.
After that, the clan, who suffered a defeat in Musashi hei ikki Riot, lost power.

sen.j: その後、庶流といわれる喜多見氏が世田谷吉良氏に仕える。
sen.e: A branch family of the Edo clan, the Kitami clan were working for the Setagaya-Kira clan.
The Kitami clan, a branch family of the Edo clan, worked for the Setagaya-Kira clan.
The Kitami clan, a branch family of the Edo clan, worked for the Setagaya-Kira clan.

sen.j: やがて、主家世田谷吉良氏やさらにその主家である後北条氏が豊臣秀吉に攻められると没落した。
sen.e: When the master house of the Setagaya-Kira clan and their master Gohojo clan were attacked by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the Edo clan also met their downfall.
Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI attacked the Setagaya-Kira clan and the Gohojo clan, its master house, which incident led to the downfall of the Kitami clan.
sen.cmt: ・「主家世田谷氏」は「喜多見氏の主である世田谷氏」と解しました。・没落したのは喜多見氏なので、修正しました。
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI attacked the Setagaya-Kira clan and the Gohojo clan, its master house, which incident led to the downfall of the Kitami clan.

sen.j: 喜多見勝忠が江戸に入府した徳川家康に仕え、世田谷喜多見に所領を与えられる。
sen.e: Katsutada KITAMI worked under Ieyasu TOKUGAWA when Ieyasu set up his Shogunate in Edo and was given a territory in Kitami, Setagaya.
Katsutada KITAMI worked for Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who entered Edo and had a territory in Kitami, Setagaya granted.
sen.cmt: 翻訳では「江戸に幕府を開いた徳川家康」となっていますが、原文ではそこまで記述されていないので、修正しました。
sen.e: Katsutada KITAMI worked for Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who entered Edo and had a territory in Kitami, Setagaya granted.

sen.j: 喜多見重政は征夷大将軍徳川綱吉の寵臣として大名に列するようになり、喜多見藩を立藩する。
sen.e: Shigemasa KITAMI became Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's favorite retainer and a Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) to start the Kirami Domain.

As Seii Taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the barbarians), Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's favorite retainer, Shigemasa KITAMI became a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and established the Kitami Domain.

As Seii Taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the barbarians), Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA's favorite retainer, Shigemasa KITAMI became a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and established the Kitami Domain.

sen.j: しかし、元禄2年(1689年)2月2日_(旧暦)に突然改易され、大名である喜多見氏は滅びた（分家の刃傷事件に連座したともされる）。
sen.e: Yet, on March 22, 1689, the rank was changed suddenly and the Daimyo Kitami clan was abolished (it is also said that they were implicated in an affair involving another branch family's sword fight).

Yet, on March 22, 1689, Shigemasa suffered kaieki (sudden dismissal and deprivation of position, privileges and properties), which incident resulted in the downfall of the Kitami clan (one theory holds that he was held responsible for one branch family's involvement in a sword fight).

Yet, on March 22, 1689, Shigemasa suffered kaieki (sudden dismissal and deprivation of position, privileges and properties), which incident resulted in the downfall of the Kitami clan (one theory holds that he was held responsible for one branch family's involvement in a sword fight).

sen.j: 江戸氏の居館跡はのちに、長禄元年(1457年)太田道灌が江戸に封じられた後江戸城として整備された。
sen.e: The remains of the residence of the Edo clan was rebuilt as the Edo-jo Castle after Dokan OTA was detained in Edo in 1457.
The remains of the residence of the Edo clan was rebuilt as Edo-jo Castle in 1457 by Dokan OTA who was assigned to Edo.
The remains of the residence of the Edo clan was rebuilt as Edo-jo Castle in 1457 by Dokan OTA who was assigned to Edo.

sen.j: 太田氏の江戸城はやがて後北条氏の支配下に置かれる。
sen.e: Ota's Edo-jo Castle later went under the rule of the Gohojo clan.
The Ota clan's Edo-jo Castle was put under the rule of the Gohojo clan later.
The Ota clan's Edo-jo Castle was put under the rule of the Gohojo clan later.

sen.j: その後徳川家康が本拠地を置き、徳川幕府が代々整備し、明治維新後は宮城となり現在の皇居となった。
sen.e: Then Ieyasu TOKUGAWA made it his home ground and the castle was looked after by generations of the Tokugawa Shogunate and became Kyujo (place where Emperor lived) after the Meiji Restoration and is the current Imperial Palace.
The castle, used as the base by Ieyasu Tokugawa and his successors, turned into Kyujo (place where Emperor lived) after the Meiji Restoration and was rebuilt as the current Imperial Palace.
The castle, used as the base by Ieyasu Tokugawa and his successors, turned into Kyujo (place where Emperor lived) after the Meiji Restoration and was rebuilt as the current Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 常陸江戸氏
sen.e: The Hitachi-Edo Clan
The Hitachi-Edo Clan
The Hitachi-Edo Clan

sen.j: 常陸国の江戸氏は本姓は藤原氏。
sen.e: The Edo clan of the Hitachi Province was a lineage of the Fujiwara clan.
The real family name of the Edo clan of Hitachi Province was Fujiwara.
The real family name of the Edo clan of Hitachi Province was Fujiwara.

sen.j: 家系は鎮守府将軍藤原秀郷を祖とする川野辺氏の支流 那珂氏を祖とす。
sen.e: The origin of the clan was the Naka clan, an offshoot of the Kawanobe clan with Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North) FUJIWARA no Hidesato as their ancestor.
The clan originated from the Naka clan, a branch family of the Kawanobe clan whose ancestor was FUJIWARA no Hidesato, Chinjufu-shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).
The clan originated from the Naka clan, a branch family of the Kawanobe clan whose ancestor was FUJIWARA no Hidesato, Chinjufu-shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).

sen.j: 那珂氏は平安時代末期に那珂郡に本拠地を置き、常陸の豪族として栄えた。
sen.e: The Naka clan had their home ground in the Naka District at the end of the Heian Period and was a powerful local ruling family in the Hitachi region.
Based in Naka County at the end of the Heian Period, the Naka clan was a powerful local ruling family in Hitachi.
Based in Naka County at the end of the Heian Period, the Naka clan was a powerful local ruling family in Hitachi.

sen.j: しかし、南北朝時代になると、宮方につき、一族の殆どが没落する。
sen.e: In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, they sided with the Southern court and most of the clan fell.
In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the clan sided with the Southern court and most of the clan members faced their downfall
In the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, the clan sided with the Southern court and most of the clan members faced their downfall

sen.j: しかし、那珂氏の一族である那珂通泰は武家方につき、那珂郡江戸郷を封ぜられ、子の江戸通高の代に江戸氏を称するようになる。
sen.e: However, Michiyasu NAKA, one of the Naka clan, sided with the samurai and blockaded Edo-go of Naka District; his son Michitaka EDO started calling himself with the family name.
However, Michiyasu NAKA, one of the Naka clan members, who sided with the samurai, was assigned to Edo-go of Naka County and his son Michitaka adopted Edo as his family name.
However, Michiyasu NAKA, one of the Naka clan members, who sided with the samurai, was assigned to Edo-go of Naka County and his son Michitaka adopted Edo as his family name.

sen.j: 通高は守護佐竹義篤 (九代当主)（佐竹氏第九代当主）の娘を娶り、度々軍功をあげた。
sen.e: Michitaka married a daughter of Shugo (provincial constable) Yoshiatsu SATAKE (ninth head of the Satake family) and established a distinguished military record.
Michitaka married a daughter of Yoshiatsu SATAKE (the ninth head of the Satake family) who was working as a Shugo (provincial constable), and sometimes established distinguished military records.
Michitaka married a daughter of Yoshiatsu SATAKE (the ninth head of the Satake family) who was working as a Shugo (provincial constable), and sometimes established distinguished military records.

sen.j: 江戸通景は本拠地を河和田(現水戸市内)に移す。
sen.e: Michikage EDO moved their base to Kawada (today's Mito City).
Michikage EDO moved his base to Kawawada (today's Mito City).
sen.cmt: 河和田は「かわわだ」が正当と思われます。
sen.e: Michikage EDO moved his base to Kawawada (today's Mito City).

sen.j: その子江戸通房の代には上杉禅秀の乱が勃発し、鎌倉公方足利持氏についた通房は、禅秀方に味方して共に没落した大掾氏の一族の馬場氏の拠点である馬場城（後の水戸城）の近辺に所領を得た。
sen.e: At the time of his son Michifusa EDO, the War of Zenshu UESUGI occurred; Michifusa fought for Kamakura Kubo Mochiuji ASHIKAGA and gained a territory near the Baba-jo Castle (later Mito-jo Castle) which was the base of the Baba clan who were one of the Daijo clan killed when they sided with Zenshu.

When the War of Zenshu UESUGI occurred, Michikage's son Michifusa supported Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the then-Kamakura kubo, and gained a territory near the Baba-jo Castle (later Mito-jo Castle) owned by the Baba clan, a family of the Daijo clan who sided with Zenshu and fell.

When the War of Zenshu UESUGI occurred, Michikage's son Michifusa supported Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, the then-Kamakura kubo, and gained a territory near the Baba-jo Castle (later Mito-jo Castle) owned by the Baba clan, a family of the Daijo clan who sided with Zenshu and fell.

sen.j: 大掾満幹はその後も馬場城を保持し続けたが、応永33年（1426年）に馬場城を留守にした隙に、通房に馬場城を攻め落とされた。
sen.e: Mitsumoto DAIJO kept holding the Baba-jo Castle even after that but when he was away in 1426, Michifusa attacked and captured the castle.
Mitsutomo DAIJO continued to occupy Baba-jo Castle even after the incident, but in 1426, Michifusa attacked and captured the castle when he was away.
Mitsutomo DAIJO continued to occupy Baba-jo Castle even after the incident, but in 1426, Michifusa attacked and captured the castle when he was away.

sen.j: 以降江戸氏は馬場城（水戸城）を本拠地として那珂川中下流部で勢力を振るう。
sen.e: Then the Edo clan wielded power in the middle to lower reach of the Naka-gawa River with the Baba-jo Castle (Mito-jo Castle) as their home ground.
Based in Baba-jo Castle (Mito-jo Castle), the Edo clan wielded power in the midstream and downstream areas of the Naka-gawa River.
Based in Baba-jo Castle (Mito-jo Castle), the Edo clan wielded power in the midstream and downstream areas of the Naka-gawa River.

sen.j: その後、守護佐竹氏の内部で山入一揆と呼ばれる内訌が発生すると積極的に介入し、佐竹領にも進出するようになる。
sen.e: When there was internal strife called the Yamairi Strife within the Shugo Satake clan, the Edo clan joined actively and started to move toward the Satake territory.

When an internal strife called the Yamairi Uprising occurred within the Satake clan serving as Shugo, the Edo clan actively intervened in the strife, which intervention was a good excuse for the Edo clan to expand their sphere of influence to the Satake Domain.

When an internal strife called the Yamairi Uprising occurred within the Satake clan serving as Shugo, the Edo clan actively intervened in the strife, which intervention was a good excuse for the Edo clan to expand their sphere of influence to the Satake Domain.

sen.j: 戦国時代_(日本)に入り、佐竹義舜が山入氏を滅ぼすことにより佐竹氏の内訌が収まり、それとともに江戸氏の北進は止まる。
sen.e: When the Sengoku Period (Warring States Period) began, the strife ended when Yoshikiyo SATAKE killed the Yamairi clan and at the same time the Edo clan stopped expanding to the north.
In the Sengoku Period (Warring States Period), the strife ended when Yoshikiyo SATAKE destroyed the Yamairi clan, which incident stopped the Edo clan's northward expansion.
In the Sengoku Period (Warring States Period), the strife ended when Yoshikiyo SATAKE destroyed the Yamairi clan, which incident stopped the Edo clan's northward expansion.

sen.j: 江戸通泰は佐竹氏に臣従の姿勢を見せたものの、独自の勢力を保ち、古河公方家の家督争いなどで混乱が続く常陸西部及び南部に進出する。
sen.e: Although Michiyasu EDO acted as a vassal to the Satake clan, he kept his own power and moved to the west and south of the Hitachi region where there were a series of disturbances such as succession disputes within the Furukawa kubo family.

Although Michiyasu EDO acted as a vassal to the Satake clan, he, independent-minded, expanded his sphere of influence to the western and southern areas of Hitachi where there were a series of disturbances such as succession disputes within the Furukawa kubo family.
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「西部、南部」は常陸の西部、南部地域と解しました。
sen.e: Although Michiyasu EDO acted as a vassal to the Satake clan, he, independent-minded, expanded his sphere of influence to the western and southern areas of Hitachi where there were a series of disturbances such as succession disputes within the Furukawa kubo family.

sen.j: 江戸忠通・江戸通政・江戸重通は佐竹義重 (十八代当主)と同盟を結び、佐竹氏は南奥に、江戸氏は常陸南部にそれぞれ積極的に進出する。
sen.e: Tadamichi EDO, Michimasa EDO and Shigemichi EDO allied with Yoshishige SATAKE (18th family head) and they both moved actively, the Satake clan to the deep-south and the Edo clan to the south of the Hitachi region.

Tadamichi EDO, Michimasa EDO and Shigemichi EDO formed an alliance with Yoshishige SATAKE (the 18th family head) and the Satake clan extended its influence to the deep south and the Edo clan to the southern areas of Hitachi.

Tadamichi EDO, Michimasa EDO and Shigemichi EDO formed an alliance with Yoshishige SATAKE (the 18th family head) and the Satake clan extended its influence to the deep south and the Edo clan to the southern areas of Hitachi.

sen.j: 重通は府中に拠点を置く大掾氏を激しく攻めたてた。
sen.e: Shigemichi fiercely attacked the Daijo clan who had their home ground in Fuchu.
Shigemichi fiercely attacked the Daijo clan who had their base in Fuchu.
Shigemichi fiercely attacked the Daijo clan who had their base in Fuchu.

sen.j: 天正18年（1590年）小田原の役がおこり、豊臣秀吉は小田原城を包囲し、関東、東北地方の諸氏に参陣を命じた。
sen.e: In 1590, when the Seige of Odawara occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and his army surrounded the Odawara-jo Castle and ordered other samurai in the Kanro and Tohoku region to join.
In 1590, when the Siege of Odawara occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and his army, surrounding Odawara-jo Castle, ordered other clans in Kanto and Tohoku to join the battle.
In 1590, when the Siege of Odawara occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and his army, surrounding Odawara-jo Castle, ordered other clans in Kanto and Tohoku to join the battle.

sen.j: 佐竹氏は後北条氏と対立し、秀吉と結びついていたことから参陣したが、後北条氏と結んでいた江戸氏は参陣しなかった。
sen.e: The Satake clan, who was opposed to the Gohojo clan, joined because they were tied with Hideyoshi but the Edo clan did not join because they had a tie with the Gohojo clan.
The Satake clan, who was opposed to the Gohojo clan, joined the battle because they had a diplomatic tie with Hideyoshi, while the Edo clan, as the Gohojo clan's ally, did not join.
The Satake clan, who was opposed to the Gohojo clan, joined the battle because they had a diplomatic tie with Hideyoshi, while the Edo clan, as the Gohojo clan's ally, did not join.

sen.j: 秀吉は佐竹義重に常陸21万貫の所領安堵状を発給する。
sen.e: Hideyoshi issued a certificate of the land of 210,000 kan of the Hitachi region to Yoshishige SATAKE.
sen.cmt: 「21万貫」は換算の必要があるようでしたらお願いします。
sen.e: Hideyoshi issued a certificate for the land of Hitachi of 210,000 kan (787,500 kg) crop yields to Yoshishige SATAKE.
sen.cmt: 一貫3.75ｋｇとして計算しました。
sen.e: Hideyoshi issued a certificate for the land of Hitachi of 210,000 kan (787,500 kg) crop yields to Yoshishige SATAKE.

sen.j: これを楯に佐竹義重は一気に南下、水戸城を落とす。
sen.e: Using this as an opportunity, Yoshishige SATAKE rushed his army down south and took the Mito-jo Castle.
It justified Yoshishige and his army in advancing southward to occupy Mito-jo Castle.
It justified Yoshishige and his army in advancing southward to occupy Mito-jo Castle.

sen.j: 重通は妻の兄である結城晴朝のもとに逃走する。
sen.e: Shigemichi ran to his wife's brother Harutomo YUKI.
Shigemichi fled to his wife's brother Harutomo YUKI.
Shigemichi fled to his wife's brother Harutomo YUKI.

sen.j: これにより江戸氏は滅亡した。
sen.e: The Edo clan came to an end at this time.
This meant the downfall of the Edo clan.
This meant the downfall of the Edo clan.

sen.j: 子孫は結城秀康に仕えたという。
sen.e: His descendants were said to have worked under Hideyasu YUKI.
His descendants are said to have worked for Hideyasu YUKI.
His descendants are said to have worked for Hideyasu YUKI.
